column4: Running "sudo nvidia-glx-config enable" returns "Error! Unable to load nvidia kernel driver! Be sure to have installed the nvidia driver for your kernel." - Kernel is 2.6.17.10, whereas linux-restricted & nvidia-glx is 2.6.17.6 - how can I get this working?
Device Manager only shows 1 Processor, I'm running a dual-core system, and the Live CD (prior to install) registered 2 - what do I need to do to get the second CPU enabled?
I ran with the default kernel
I ran the update, but didn't switch kernel versions/types
what does 'uname -r' give you?
the -generic kernel might not be the generic kernel, if that makes sense :P
then you are not running the -generic kenrel :)
just do the 'sudo apt-get install linux-image-generic' and reboot
yes, the depends for the nvidia-glx package are broken
before you do anything else, you must install linux-restricted-modules-generic, or you wont be able to start x with the default kernel
when thats done, you can just uninstall all the -386 or -686 kernels
then you should be fine
no it shouldnt. before you reboot, you could remove the kernels you dont want :)
its usualy no problem to remove even the running kernel, since youll be rebooting anyway :)
the easies way it to remove the kernels you dont want :P
id like to know as well. highlight me if you find out, please? :)
will do
thanks :)
https://help.ubuntu.com/community/ChangeTTYResolution - change terminal resolution.  I was only able to change my 20" LCD (native 1600x1200) to 1280x1024, any higher and grub pukes so far
thank you. :) whats up with grub?
I think its more a VESA/VGA issue than grub, some cards/monitors don't support higher res until the OS kicks in it seems :-/
